Constitution of India - Arts. 21, 14, 32 and 142 - Criminal investigation - Right of accused to fair and impartial investigation and freedom from arbitrary, unlawful arrest - Prayer seeking change of investigating agency/constitution of Special Investigation Team and court- monitored investigation - Maintainability and scope of exercise of power - Allegation of improper investigation and arrest of eminent human rights activists and invocation of UAPA, with intent to curb dissenting voice which differed from ideology of party in power - Plea of lack of evidence as basis for impugned investigation and arrests based thereupon, seriously disputed by investigating agency - Held (pe r majority) , there is no need to go into disputed questions of fact or else it would prejudice trial - Accused has no say in choice of investigating agency or manner of investigation - But court can pass appropriate directions if there has been mala fide exercise of power by investigating officer - However, present writ petitioners not alleging any specific fact about mala fide exercise of power by investigating agency -There were communal and caste clashes and incidents of stone throwing and arson due to alleged provocative speeches, slogans and distribution of objectionable and provocative book s and pamphlets in events allegedly organised by accused through banned organisation CPI (Maoist) - Though said allegations, disputed - Prayer seeking appointment of SIT and court-monitored investigation, rejected - Court has to exercise this extraordinary power with caution - CBI cannot be unnecessarily overburdened with cases - Alternative remedy available under substantive and procedural criminal law - Accused have already resort ed to such remedy and can avail such remedies - If th ere is no evidence against them, they may as well be discharged by competent court (Paras 1, 2 and 22 to 34) - Per Chandrachud, J. ( dissenting), on facts, a case has been made out for constitution of SIT - Conduct of State Government police ag ency is such that it casts a doubt on the credibility of their investigation - Investigating team violated directions in D.K. Constitution of India - Art. 32 - Maintainability - Locus Standi/ Standing - Cross-cases/FIRs - Standing to challenge cross-FIR - Communal and cast e clashes, and incidents of stone throwing and arson - Earlier FIR against violence by upper caste who were enraged by meetings arranged by group of present accused person s - Later FIR was against present accused persons for organising said meetings through a banned organisation and raising of provocative speeches, slogans in such meeting - Accused persons, held, per majority, cannot seek relief in respect of earlier FIR - Earlier FIR can at best be a cross-FIR in respect of same incident (Para 31) - Per Chandrachud, J. ( dissenting), alleged meeting by petitioner-accused persons herein, was a historical event and the Vijay Stambh was a symbolic rallying ground for the annual event to celebrate the victory of lower castes during a colonial battle - The event represents aspirations of those who have been subjected to discrimination and prejudice in the caste-ridden structure of society - Said meeting was even attend e d by a retired Judge of Supreme Court (Paras 45 to 53) Communal and caste clashes, stone throwing and arson incidents took place due to alleged meetings and events organised by accused persons through a banned organisation, CPI (Maoist) and through provocative speeches, slogans and distribution of objectionable and provocative books and pamphlets. The present writ petition is filed alleging improper investigation with a prayer to change investigating agency or direct court-monitored investigation. The writ petitioner s alleged that five illustrious persons were arrested amongst others in connection with said caste clashes, and provisions of UAPA had been invoked, with a view to kill their independent voic es which diff ered from the ideology of the party in power. Rejecting the prayer for change of inve stigating agency and/or court-monitored investigation and also rejecting other prayers in relation to manner of investigation and arrest, the Supreme Court Held: Per majority Five illustrious persons in their own field have filed this petition on 29-8-2018 complaining that the five activists, namely, Gautam N avalakha, Sudha Bharadwaj, Vara vara Rao, Arun Ferreira and Vernon Gonsalves were arrested on 28-8-2018 from their homes at New Delhi, Faridabad, Mumbai, Thane and Hyderabad, respectively, without any credible material and evidence against them justifying their arrest, purportedly in connection with FIR No. 0004 of 2018 dated 8-1-2018 registered with Police Station Vishram Bagh, Pune City. (Para 30) A fortiori, it must follow that the writ petitioners, who are strangers to the offence under investigation (in FIR No. 4 of 2018); and since they are merely espousing the cause of the arrested five accused as their next friends, cannot be heard to ask for the reliefs which otherwise cannot be granted to the accused themselves. What cannot be done directly, cannot be allowed to be done indirectly even in the guise of public interest litigation. (Para 32) Accordingly, this writ petition is disposed of with liberty to the accused concerned to take recourse to appropriate remedy as may be permissible in law. The interim order passed by the Court on 29-8-2018 shall continue for a period of four weeks to enable the accused to move the court concerned. The said proceedings shall be decided on its own merits uninfluenced by any observation made in this judgment, which is limited to the reliefs claimed in the writ petition to transfer the investigation to an independent investigating agency and/or court-monitored investigation. The investigating officer is free to proceed against the accused concerned as per law. All the accompanying applications are also disposed of in terms of this judgment. (Para 40) E. Sivakumar v. Liberty and freedom are defining values of our Constitution. The g institutional role of the Court as a constitutional adjudicator should brook no technicalities which obstruct the cause of justice. Union of India , 2018 SCC OnLine SC 1343, referred to Though the prayer seeking the appointment of a Special Investigating Team is sought to be introduced by way of an application for amendment, it is necessary to note that in the petition as it was originally filed, it has been stated that the object of the petition is not to stop an investigation but to ensure an independent and credible investigation. (Para 65) Public interest litigation should not become a weapon for settling political scores or of pursuing extraneous ends. In the present case, there is no manner of doubt that the initiation of the proceedings under Article 32 is not motivated by extraneous reasons. The law is not a respecter of social, economic or political status and every litigant who seeks access to justice has to be treated evenly. (Para 66) Over the course of the last decade, the jurisdiction of the Court has evolved under Article 32 to order the constitution of a SIT. These instances indicate the diversity of settings in which the Supreme Court has ordered the constitution of SITs. Decisional flexibility in the exercise of this jurisdiction meets exigencies which arise in unforeseen situations, warranting the intervention of the Supreme Court under Article 142. While the Court does not determine the course of the investigation, it acts as a watchdog to ensure that a fair and impartial investigation takes place. The expression of a finding by the Supreme Court would affect the administration of criminal justice or perhaps in a given case, even the rights of the accused. The observations of the Court must, therefore, be confined to assessing whether a case has been made out for the constitution of a SIT and matters having a bearing on that decision. (Para 71) The Court must, at the outset, dwell on the fairness of the manner in which the police have approached this investigation. (Para 72) There is a growing tendency among investigating officers ( either police or other departments) to inform the media, even before the completion of investigation, that they have caught a criminal or an offender. Such crude attempts to claim credit for imaginary investigational breakthroughs should be curbed. (Para 73) Rajendran Chingaravelu v. R.K. Mishra, (2010) 1 SCC 457: (2010) 1 SCC (Cri) 810, referred to This facet of the case is of serious concern. The manner in which the Joint Commissioner of Police and the Additional Director General of Police (Law and Order), Maharashtra have selectively disclosed purported details of the investigation to the media and on television channels casts a cloud on the impartiality of the investigative process. (Para 74) During the course of the hearing, the Additional Solicitor General has assisted the Court by tendering the case diary and a compilation of documentary material. As a matter of prudence, the Court must desist from adverting to the details contained in the compilation or in the case diary save and except for indicating broad reasons in the course of evaluating the reliefs which have been claimed. (Para 75) The Court has perused the compilation produced. The allegation that each of the five individuals arrested on 28-8-2018 is found to be engaged in activities of the nature set out in para 26 of the counter-affidavit is taking liberties with the truth. General allegations against the philosophy of a banned organisation, its policies a b C d e and the modalities followed in the execution of its unlawful activities constitute one thing. Linking this to specific activities of named individuals is a distinct matter. At f this stage, it is necessary to note the submission which has been urged in regard to an undated letter of Sudha Bhardwaj to Comrade Prakash which was also allegedly distributed to the media. There is a serious bone of contention in regard to the authenticity of the letter which, besides being undated, does not contain any details including the e-mail header. A statement has been handed over to the Court in support of the submission that the letter is an obvious fabrication made by a Marathi g speaking person because in as many as 17 places, it contains references to words scribed in Devanagari, using forms peculiar to Marathi. It has been urged that Sudha Bhardwaj who does not belong to Maharashtra and is not Marathi speaking, could not possibly have written a letter in Devanagari utilising essentially Marathi forms of grammar or address. There is no need to delve deep into these aspects at this stage, since they are matters for a fair investigation. KHANWILKAR, J. (for Dipak Misra, C.J. and himself; e Chandrachud, J. dissenting)- Five illustrious persons in their own field have filed this petition on 29-8-2018 complaining about the high-handed action of Maharashtra Police in raiding the homes and arresting five well-known human rights activists, journalists, advocates and political worker, with a view to kill independent voices differing in ideology from the party in power and to stifle the honest voice of dissent.
